bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to William Howard Taft, April 1, 1905

div1.p: Gorgas responds to criticisms of Charles A. Reed. He presents an analysis of the Canal Zone Commission organization.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to William Howard Taft, April 1, 1905
div1.opener:
ISTHMIAN CANAL COMMISSION
OFFICE OF CHIEF SANITARY OFFICER
ANCON, CANAL ZONE.
April 1, 1905.
Hon. W. H. Taft,
Secretary of War, Washington, D.C.
(Through the Governor of the Canal Zone)
Sir:-
div1.p:
In your letter of March 17th to the President in regard to
a report made by Dr. C.L. Reed you used the following language:

“The reply of the Commission seems to show that a
large part of the plans and the action of the Commission,
which Dr. Reed criticises, was fully concurred in and
agreed to by Colonel Gorgas and the other medical officers
in the employ of the Commission. It is, doubtless, true
that Colonel Gorgas and his staff believed that it would
be wiser to give them an entirely free hand in the
matter of ordering construction, supplies and the employ-
ment of subordinates. It is quite probable that had
the approval of the Commission in the matter of ordering
construction and supplies been dispensed with, there would
have been fewer delays and less complaint on this
account, but in the expenditure of such large sums as were
necessary for the organization of the sanitary system,
the construction of plants and the purchase of supplies,
it may well be doubted whether the Commission would
have been discharging its duty in withholding supervisory
control.”

Either from Dr. Reed's report or other sources of
information you are evidently under the impression that I,
as head of the Sanitary Department, wished to make expenditure
without the approval of the Commission. In other words, that
I proposed such a plan as this:

That the Commission, for the year 1904, should place
2:-
at my disposal $1,000,000, and that I should spend this as I
thought best for the benefit of the Sanitary Department.

Nothing that I have ever said or written can fairly
be construed into any such proposition. My experience as a
government official for the last twenty-five years has taught
me that any such proposition as this would be entirely illegal;
and if it were legal, I would not wish to have any such un-
necessary responsibility. What I have always proposed, and still
urge, is some such scheme as this:

That I make a yearly, quarterly, or monthly estimate
to the Commission, as they think best, and the estimate would
be in the usual form such as this:

Salary of Superintendent of Ancon Hospital $6,000
Two physicians, each 2,400
Medicines and medical supplies for 500 patients 10,000
Subsistence for 500 patients 75,000
Miscellaneous expenditures for maintenance of
hospital and care of patients not otherwise
mentioned 500
etc,etc.

This estimate would be submitted to the Commission
and their action upon it would be law, which would limit me
in expenditure to the sums mentioned in the estimate. I would
wish to have the Disbursing Officer assigned to the Sanitary
Department, or some one designated as Disbursing Officer for the
Sanitary Department. The sum approved by the Commission
would then be placed to his credit, and he could make disburse-
ments subject to law as any other disbursing officer does. I
would like also to have an officer especially assigned to the
3:-
Sanitary Department who would perform the functions for the
Sanitary Department that the Chief of Material & Supplies at the
present time does for the Canal at large; but in a small
department, such as the Sanitary Department, the functions of
both of these offices might very well be combined in one and
the same man do both the disbursing and the purchasing. I
would also wish to have a competent constructor assigned to
the Sanitary Department to look after the construction and
repairs.

And for these reasons:---I think I can make myself
clearer by taking an instance. Take the screening of the fever
wards at our main hospital, Ancon. This matter was estimated
for in July; the Commission in August acted upon the estimate,
modified it and authorized such screening as they thought
advisable. Since that time the matter has entirely passed out
of my hands and the wards are still unscreened. I brought the
matter to the Governor's attention quite a number of times
and the Governor has each time written to the Washington authori-
ties on the subject. I mention this subject of screens as it
is probably one of the most important sanitary measures that
could come up, and one in which I have used every possible
endeavor to expedite matters.

Under the Proposed organization the routine would
have been as follows:

The estimate would have gone to the Commission, as
it did in July; they would have acted upon it, as they did
in August. As soon as it had been acted upon I would have
directed my disbursing officer to purchase the necessary
material and the constructing officer to do the constructing.
4:-
If the material was to have been gotten from the United States,
which it probably would have been, it would not have taken
more than six weeks, and all the screening, authorized by
the Commission, should have been put up in another six weeks.
In other words this most important piece of sanitation, under
my organization, I think, should have been finished within
three months. Under the present organization, eight months
after it was asked for, it has not even been commenced, nor
can I even guess at what time it will be commenced. As Sanitary
Officer of the city of Havanna for nearly four years I had
this organization and accomplished matters just as I describe.
When anything was authorized by the proper authorities I could
very rapidly bring it about.

Another important point in the efficiency of the
Department is that it should be attached and dependent upon
none of the other sub-divisions on the Isthmus, but its Chief
should report directly to the supreme authority. It is one
of the most important departments under the control of the
Commission, both in the vital importance of the work it has
to do and in the number of its employees.

The functions and duties of the Department are
much varied, coming more generally and intimately in contact
with the engineers than with any others. It is also the
health authorities, representing the Republic of Panama in Colon
and the city of Panama.

The reasons that make it desirable for the
Governor, Chief Engineer, Chief of Material and Supplies,
Paymaster, etc. to report directly to the Commission or to the
5:-
supreme authority could apply as well to the Sanitary Department
and with even more potency.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully yours, (Sgd) W.C. Gorgas
Chief Sanitary Officer.
